content.text: Using Fig. 1.1
• record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the cold water in beaker \(\mathbf{A},\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{A}} =\)
• record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the warm water in beaker \(\mathbf{B}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{B}} =\)
The test-tubes of hot water are placed into beakers \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\)
The students record the temperatures \(\theta\) of the water in the test-tubes every 30s. Their readings are shown in Table 1.1
Complete the units and the time column in Table 1.1

table.html:
timetube in beaker A with cold watertube in beaker B with warm water
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)

content.text: Describe two precautions that you would take, before reading the thermometer, to ensure that the temperature readings are as accurate as possible in the experiment
Write a conclusion stating how increasing the temperature of the surrounding water affects the rate of cooling of the water in the test-tube
Justify your answer by reference to the results in Table 1.1
Suggest one change to the experiment shown in Fig. 1.1 to ensure that the comparison of the effect of surrounding temperature on cooling is a fair test
Explain why the change is an improvement
change
explanation
The students use a measuring cylinder to measure \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water
Describe briefly how to read a measuring cylinder to obtain an accurate value for the volume of water. You may draw a diagram
Some students are investigating how the surrounding temperature affects the rate at which water cools
They are using the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected so that it will measure the potential difference across wire \(\mathbf{A}\)
In the first line of Table 2.1, record the potential difference \(V\) and current \(I\) for wire \(\mathbf{A}\), as shown in Figs. 2.2 and 2.3
Fig. 2.2 Fig. 2.3
The student connects the crocodile clips to wire \(\mathbf{B}\) and then wire \(\mathbf{C}\) in turn. His readings of potential difference and current are shown in Table 2.1
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of each wire
Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Calculate the resistance per unit length \(r\) of each wire using the equation \(r = \frac{R}{l}\). Include the unit
r for wire \(\mathbf{A} =\)
r for wire \(\mathbf{B} =\)
r for wire \(\mathbf{C} =\)
Another student suggests that \(r\) should be the same for each wire
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement with reference to your results
statement
justification
The student measures the length of each wire to be tested
On Fig. 2.4, draw an arrow (➔) to indicate **precisely** between which two points he should measure \(l\)
One possible problem with this type of experiment is heating of the resistance wires
Suggest a precaution that could be taken to reduce this
A student is investigating the resistance of three wires \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\). He is using the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1
The circuit is set up to test wire \(\mathbf{A}\). The length, \(l\) of each wire is measured and recorded
A student sets the distance \(u\) between the illuminated triangle and the lens to \(20.0 \text{cm}\). She moves the screen until a sharp image of the triangle is seen on the screen
The student measures the height of the illuminated triangle \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\)
Measure and record, in Table 3.1, the height of the image of the triangle \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) on the screen, as shown in Fig. 3.2
The student measures the height \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) of the image for \(u\) values of \(25.0 \text{cm}, 35.0 \text{cm}, 45.0 \text{cm}\) and \(55.0 \text{cm}\). Her results are shown in Table 3.1
For each value of \(u\), calculate and record in Table 3.1 a value for the magnification \(M\)
Use the equation \(M = \frac{h_{\mathrm{I}}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\) and the value of \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) from **(a)**
Plot a graph of \(M\) (y-axis) against \(u / \text{cm}\) (x-axis)
From your graph, determine the value of \(u\) when \(M = 1.0\). Show clearly on your graph how you obtained the information
u =
Describe one difficulty that might be experienced when measuring the height of the image in this experiment. Suggest one improvement to the apparatus to overcome this
difficulty
improvement
When setting up the apparatus, the student makes sure that the card with the illuminated triangle, the lens and the screen are all perpendicular to the bench
Explain why this is an important precaution in this experiment
Some students are investigating the magnification produced by a converging lens
They are using the apparatus shown in Fig. 3.1
A student is investigating how the material of a spring affects its behaviour when stretched
The following apparatus is available to the student:
wires of different thickness, length and material
a set of \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses and a set of \(100\mathrm{g}\) masses, both with hangers
a wooden rod approximately \(1\mathrm{cm}\) in diameter
other standard laboratory equipment
Plan an experiment which will enable you to test the extension of springs made from different types of wire
In your plan, you should include:
• instructions for making a spring from the wire that is provided,
• what you will measure,
• instructions for carrying out the experiment,
• the variables you will keep the same to ensure the comparison is a fair test,
• any precaution which should be taken or difficulty which might occur,
how you will present your results
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
